event.value: Sandy buys out his co-owners to found the Allan Line, which, at that point, consisted of just the one ship: Jean.

occupation.value: Sailor. Initially as mate to Captain John Wilson of Saltcoats but soon after as Master and part-owner of several first-class ships trading out of Saltcoats.

individual.note: Sir Alexander Tilloch Galt was his first cousin.

source-citation.page: Linen Hall Library; Belfast, Northern Ireland; Periodicals & Newspapers, Irish & Reference

property.value: Hugh buys part of the estate of Simon McTavish to build Ravenscrag.

residence.value: The building work is complete.

occupation.value: Commission merchant for one of the city's leading importers.

event.value: Hugh took a year off from work to travel through his native Scotland, London, New York and Upper Canada.

occupation.value: Clerk for grain merchant, William Kerr.
Working at his family's counting house: Allan, Kerr & Co.

place.place-name: Greenock Old or West, Renfrewshire, Scotland

occupation.value: Managing the Liverpool branch of his father's shipping business.

place.place-name: Old Rome Ford, Gatehead, Ayrshire, Scotland
Kilmarnock Low Churchyard, Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, Scotland

residence.value: A 300 acre farm. Gilbert was the tennant.
Living with her son Gilbert.
In a clay cottage that William designed and built.

event.value: It's believed that this is where Agnes and William Burnes first met.

individual.education: Agnes attended a dame school held in a weaver's cottage and learned psalms by heart, acquired basic reading skills but did not learn to write.

birth.value: The midwife attending was Agnes McClure, their next-door neighbour.

residence.value: Lodging with his aunt, Jean Brown.

place.place-name: Old Rome Ford, Gatehead, Ayrshire, Scotland

individual.note: Eldest son of 7 children. He had at least 13 children of his own: 9 with his wife Jean and 4+ by other women.

place.place-name: Old Burgher Churchyard, Pollockshaws, Renfrewshire, Scotland

adoption.value: Taken in by her father and his wife.

source-citation.page: London Metropolitan Archives; London, England; Reference Number: p89/mry1/181

individual.occupation: Servant to the mother of Robert Burns

individual.military: Joined the 26th Regiment and served in India from 1829 to 1840 until his regiment was sent to China, where he was killed.
individual.education: Apprenticed as a baker but left to join the Army.

individual.military: Petty Officer in the Royal Navy. Served at Navarino and in the Crimea.

individual.note: John was an orphan and was raised by his uncle, Mr Campbell of Roughdyke Farm in Sorn.

source-citation.page: London Metropolitan Archives; London, England; Reference Number: p89/mry1/181

place.place-name: Old Burgher Churchyard, Pollockshaws, Renfrewshire, Scotland

individual.military: A private in the Stirlingshire Militia. Until 1814.

individual.military: Rear-Admiral. Engaged in battle with the enemy more than 100 times and was mentioned in dispatches 8 times for gallantry.
